title: fixed initial state of password box
body: Fixes the initial state of the password input field according to https://github.com/Microsoft/react-native-windows/issues/1934

title: Replace defunct Winium CI test with working Appium test
body:
Add an Appium (WinAppDriver) test.
Remove Winium JS tests.
Remove jasmine dependency since new Appium test uses NUnit for the runner (WinAppDriver doesn't support JS runner yet).
Note: Appium test uses CI environment variables, and defaults to c:\bin\x86\ReleaseBundle if they aren't set.

title: Fix fontStyle exception on WPF
body:
Fix fontStyle exception on WPF and unify all fontStyle parser to FontStyleHelpers.ParseFontStyle().
This is the same as the #1191 pull request with plus an aesthetic fix.

title: Adding option to opt-out of bundle caching and always contact the development server
body:
If the JavaScript is changed between runs of the application the bundle loaded will not demonstrate the changes until Ctrl+R is executed.  This breaks the previous developer cycle of  being able to change the JavaScript and having those changes reflected on the next application run.

This was changed when the "HasUpToDateBundleInCache" check was added to the "ReactInstanceManager.CreateReactContextFromDevManagerAsync()" that will load the packager bundle from cache if it is up to date.

@rozele We discussed the possibility of adding a flag to allow the old behavior to be restored.  This is what I've done in this PR.  I've added a flag called "UseBundleCaching" to the ReactPage and ReactInstanceManager that will set the IsBundleCachingEnabled flag on the IDevSupportManager.  If the flag is true and the cached bundle is up to date then the "CreateReactContextFromCachedPackagerBundleAsync" is executed;  Otherwise the _devSupportManager.CreateReactContextFromPackagerAsync is executed.

I have chosen to set the default for the new flag to "true" so that the existing behavior is not changed.  Let me know if you'd like the flag to be false by default, which will force anybody who wants to use the bundle caching to opt-in rather than the other way around.

title: ClipboardModule could throw exception if clipboard is already opened by another process
body:
The WPF ClipboardModule will throw the following COMException if the clipboard is already opened by another process:

"OpenClipboard Failed (Exception from HRESULT: 0x800401D0 (CLIPBRD_E_CANT_OPEN)"

title: feat(Fluent.AcrylicBrush): Add support for the acrylic brushes
body:
This change adds new View properties:

- `acrylicOpacity` makes the element semi-transparent
- `acrylicSource` defaults to `"host"`
- `acrylicTintColor` is allowed to have alpha-channel

For detailed description of the properties see
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/uwp/style/acrylic

**This change requires RS3 SDK + VS2017 to compile.**

#1404

title: Calls to InvokeFunction and InvokeCallback on the bridge should wait until the bridge is intialized
body:
…until bridge is initialized.

Currently calls to InvokeFunction and InvokeCallback either cause an NullReferenceException or InvalidOperationException if they are called before the bridge is initialized. But the initialization of bridge happens asynchronously and in parallel to other RN module load. There is no way for the modules to know the initialization state of the bridge. So it is not possible to externally control the invocation of these methods.

As a fix, when InvokeFunction or InvokeCallback is called, we execute them if the bridge is there, otherwise we stash them and add them back to the queue when it gets initialized.

title: NetInfo: Added “connectionChange" event  since “change” event is deprecated.
body:
**Issue description**: 
The “change” event is deprecated and warns when used. “connectionChange" event implementation is missing in both UWP and WPF platforms.

**Expected behaviour**:
 I expect “connectionChange" event should work like as in iOS and Android.

**Proposed Solution** 
Added “connectionChange" support on both platforms (UWP and WPF). This provides access to ConnectionType and EffectiveConnectionType to determine connection level as well as connection type.  
Note: The updated code does not impact existing “change” event interfaces.

**Following test cases are executed:**

**Sample Code:**
NetInfo.addEventListener(
  'connectionChange',
  handleFirstConnectivityChange
);

function handleFirstConnectivityChange(connectionInfo) {
  console.log('type: ' + connectionInfo.type + ', effectiveType: ' + connectionInfo.effectiveType);
}

**ON UWP app:**

**Connected to WIFI**
 log:  type: “InternetAccess”, effectiveType: “unknown”

**Disconnected from WIFI**
log: type: “none”, effectiveType: “unknown”

**Connected to LAN**
 log:  type: “InternetAccess”, effectiveType: “unknown”

**Disconnected from LAN**
log: type: “none”, effectiveType: “unknown”

**Connected to Mobile Data (LTE) - Tested on Windows Phone**
 log:  type: “InternetAccess”, effectiveType: “4g”

**Disconnected from Mobile Data (LTE)**
log: type: “none”, effectiveType: “unknown”

**ON WPF app:**

**Connected to WIFI**
 log:  type: “InternetAccess”, effectiveType: “unknown”

**Disconnected from WIFI**
log: type: “none”, effectiveType: “unknown”

**Connected to LAN**
 log:  type: “InternetAccess”, effectiveType: “unknown”

**Disconnected from LAN**
log: type: “none”, effectiveType: “unknown”

**Connected to Mobile Data (LTE)**
 Not applicable

**Disconnected from Mobile Data (LTE)**
Not applicable

I have submitted a PR with a proposed solution. Please review.

title: Dispose context on initialization error
body: Another tricky issue when reloading instances found and fixed by a colleague.

title: Documentation: Add how to hide Performance stats black boxes
body:
It's just a small change to the Readme about how to hide the debug performance counters/stats but it wasn't mentioned anywhere yet.

At some point it may be better to move it to the UserProject in the solution so it's configurable by the user without having to open internals.

title: Implementation of the PopUp Menu in UIManagerModule
body:
This pull request implements PopUp menus for Windows (UWP) (See #212). It internally uses UWP's MenuFlyout, being able to anchor on a definable view.
The implementation has been done by keeping the one of Android in mind. On Android, success callbacks retrieve one or two arguments:

1) The event type
  -> "dismissed" if the popup has been dismissed
  -> "itemSelected" if an item has been selected
2) (Optional) The index of the selected item

For this reason, the ACTION_DISMISSED and ACTION_ITEM_SELECTED constants from the UIManagerModule had to be made public.
Furthermore, the method signature of the ShowPopupMenu function in NativeViewHierarchyManager had to be modified to include the error callback.
This error callback is present in the ShowPopupMenu function of the UIManagerModule, but it has not been passed to the previously mentioned function.
This callback is needed for the same reason than in the Android implementation: to forward errors about unknown anchor views to the JavaScript code.

title: Track pending JS calls to allow for monitoring of bridge traffic
body:
Pulled from RN Android: 
https://github.com/facebook/react-native/blob/4466b6fa7ce5325cac3233a23b10ffcb4ff038a7/ReactAndroid/src/main/java/com/facebook/react/bridge/CatalystInstanceImpl.java#L469

It enables some shutdown safety and performance monitoring hooks like this one: 
https://github.com/facebook/react-native/blob/26684cf3adf4094eb6c405d345a75bf8c7c0bf88/ReactAndroid/src/main/java/com/facebook/react/modules/debug/FpsDebugFrameCallback.java

(I'd prefer to do an impl of FpsDebugFrameCallback in a separate PR.)

Thanks to my colleagues @takesui and @yuichiando for doing the port, integration, and testing work!

title: Add Hyperlink view to React.Shared text
body:
Adds a hyperlink view, inherited from ReactSpanViewManager, to allow hyperlinks to show correctly on UWP / WPF.  

The Windows hyperlink control will automatically change the mouse pointer to indicate that the link is clickable.

title: Yoga Node leak fix
body:
This fixes a memory leak noted by a profiler in an app.

Fix deployed, works in app. Ran Net46 and UWP unit tests, and tested Playground.

title: breaking(IReactContext): Extract IReactContext from ReactContext, make ThemedReactContext pure delegation
Exception when tearing down root view before it has finished being initialized
Text inline views break `pointerEvents` behavior
body:
### Environment

<!--
  Please fill in all the relevant fields by running these commands in terminal.
-->

1. `react-native -v`: *
2. `npm ls rnpm-plugin-windows`: *
3. `npm ls react-native-windows`: *
4. `node -v`: *
5. `npm -v`: *
6. `yarn --version`<!-- (if you use Yarn) -->: *

Then, specify:

<!-- (What platform are you building for? Choose any from UWP, WPF) -->
- Target Platform: *

<!-- (What framework version are you building for? Choose from 10.0.14393, 10.0.10586, 10.0.10240, etc. (UWP), .NET 4.6.1, .NET 4.5, etc. (WPF) -->
- Target Platform Version(s): *

<!-- (What device(s) are you targeting? Choose any from Desktop, Mobile (ARM), Mobile Emulator, Xbox, Hololens) -->
- Target Device(s): *

<!-- Which operating system are you using? Specify macOS, Windows, or Linux, along with specific release versions -->
- Development Operating System: *

<!-- Which version of Visual Studio are you using? Specify Visual Studio 2015 or Visual Studio 2017 -->
- Visual Studio Version: *

### Steps to Reproduce

<!--
  How would you describe your issue to someone who doesn’t know you or your project?
  Try to write a sequence of steps that anybody can repeat to see the issue.
  Be specific! If the bug cannot be reproduced, your issue may be closed.
-->

(Write your steps here:)

1. Create a `<Text>` component with a nested `<View>` component
2. Add the `<Text/>` component to parent `<View pointerEvents='none'>` component
3. Wrap the whole thing in a `<TouchableWithoutFeedback>` component and add an `onPress` handler.
4. Click the text inline view.

### Expected Behavior

<!--
  How did you expect your project to behave?
  It’s fine if you’re not sure your understanding is correct.
  Just write down what you thought would happen.
-->

When you click the text inline view, the Touchable should not fire the `onPress` handler.

### Actual Behavior

<!--
  Did something go wrong?
  Is something broken, or not behaving as you expected?
  Describe this section in detail, and attach screenshots if possible.
  Don't just say "it doesn't work"!
-->

The `onPress` handler fires.

### Reproducible Demo

<!--
  Please share a project that reproduces the issue.
  There are two ways to do it:

    * Create a new app using https://snack.expo.io/ and try to reproduce the issue in it.
      This is useful if you roughly know where the problem is, or can’t share the real code.

    * Or, copy your app and remove things until you’re left with the minimal reproducible demo.
      This is useful for finding the root cause. You may then optionally create a Snack.

  This is a good guide to creating bug demos: https://stackoverflow.com/help/mcve
  Once you’re done, copy and paste the link to the Snack or a public GitHub repository below:
-->

Here's a sample you can paste into the Playground app to reproduce:
```
class Playground extends Component {
  render() {
    return (
      <TouchableWithoutFeedback onPress={() => alert('Error!')}>
        <View 
          pointerEvents='none'
          style={styles.container}>
          <Text style={styles.welcome}>
            Click the inner view, hope you don't get an alert!
            <View style={{width: 10, height: 10, backgroundColor: 'red'}} />
          </Text>
        </View>
      </TouchableWithoutFeedback>
    );
  }
}
```

When you click the inline view (the red box), the alert fires even though the click occurred inside the context of `pointerEvents: none`.

<!--
  What happens if you skip this step?

  Someone will read your bug report, and maybe will be able to help you,
  but it’s unlikely that it will get much attention from the team. Eventually,
  the issue will likely get closed in favor of issues that have reproducible demos.

  Please remember that:

    * Issues without reproducible demos have a very low priority.
    * The person fixing the bug would have to do that anyway. Please be respectful of their time.
    * You might figure out the issues yourself as you work on extracting it.

  Thanks for helping us help you!
-->

title: feat(DragAndDrop): Implemented drag & drop events for files
body:
This change adds 1 property and 4 event handlers to `ReactViewManager`:
- `allowDrop=true` enables the view as a drop target. This is same as the XAML `AllowDrop` property.
- `onDragEnter` simply translates the XAML event to JS.
- `onDragLeave` simply translates the XAML event to JS.
- `onDragOver` sends the event to JS, but doesn't let it change the `AllowDrop` property on the fly.
- `onDrop` sends the event with file descriptors.

Example of the event object given to `onDrop`:
```js
{ target: 8,
  dataTransfer: 
   { files: 
      [ { name: 'logo.png',
          size: 96548,
          type: 'image/png',
          uri: 'urn:future-access-list:%7B7420FE1A-D413-43B4-AAE4-C2C3745910D5%7D' },
        { name: 'Releases.md',
          size: 8142,
          type: '',
          uri: 'urn:future-access-list:%7BF8B97F3E-4265-41B5-8D3C-07857D1C6134%7D' } ],
     items: 
      [ { kind: 'file', type: 'image/png' },
        { kind: 'file', type: '' } ],
     types: [ 'image/png', '' ] } }
```

Notable differences from how this works in XAML:
- `allowDrop=true` is set only once and allows to drop any kind of items. In XAML this property can be changed in the `DragOver` handler to allow only certain types of files or items. Thus the `onDragOver` event sent to JS is notification only: JS can see what's being dropped, but cannot stop that or change the cursor icon.
- The `onDrop` event carries the list of dropped files and only files. This change doesn't support drag & drop for text or other items. The list of files sent to JS is just a list of file uris and file metadata (name, size, etc.).

There is an important detail. In UWP an app cannot access arbitrary files by their path, unless these files are in the app folder (the one that contains `LocalState`, `LocalCache` and other dirs). However the user can drag & drop files from anywhere, so if RNW sends paths of these files, the app won't be able to read them. The workaround is to use `FutureAccessList` (FAL):
1. RNW gets a list of `StorageFile` objects from the XAML `Drop` event.
2. Every file object is put to FAL and RNW gets a list of FAL tokens (GUIDs).
3. RNW sends to JS the tokens wrapped into a `urn:future-access-list:{GUID}` format.

JS cannot use these FAL tokens directly, but it can send them to another RN module that can extract the file objects from FAL using the tokens. The problem is that now JS and other RN modules need to understand this FAL concept.

title: Race condition when multiple apps load from debug server simultaneously
body:
### Environment

<!--
  Please fill in all the relevant fields by running these commands in terminal.
-->

1. `react-native -v`: 2.0.1 / master (pre-0.55)
4. `node -v`: 8.9.4
5. `npm -v`: 5.6

Then, specify:

<!-- (What platform are you building for? Choose any from UWP, WPF) -->
- Target Platform: UWP

<!-- (What framework version are you building for? Choose from 10.0.14393, 10.0.10586, 10.0.10240, etc. (UWP), .NET 4.6.1, .NET 4.5, etc. (WPF) -->
- Target Platform Version(s): RS4

<!-- (What device(s) are you targeting? Choose any from Desktop, Mobile (ARM), Mobile Emulator, Xbox, Hololens) -->
- Target Device(s): Desktop and Xbox

<!-- Which operating system are you using? Specify macOS, Windows, or Linux, along with specific release versions -->
- Development Operating System: Windows 10 RS4

<!-- Which version of Visual Studio are you using? Specify Visual Studio 2015 or Visual Studio 2017 -->
- Visual Studio Version: VS2017 15.6.6

### Steps to Reproduce

The DevSupportManager interface does not support the multi-window/app use case. When multiple apps are loading from the debug server simultaneously, they all attempt write the bundle to ReactNativeDevBundle.js concurrently. Generally, only the last application to attempt to write to the file wins.
The suggested fix is for DevSupportManager to load the bundle from the debug server directly into memory (instead of writing to disk at a hardcoded path), to avoid this race condition.

cc @rigdern @reseul

title: feat(Interfaces): Extract pure interfaces, abstract classes, and primitives into separate build artifact
body: Create ReactNative.Interfaces and move most pure interfaces, abstract… classes, related Exception and EventArgs there. Extract IReactContext, IReactChoreographer, and parameterize. Add primitive properties to IMutableFrameEventArgs to allow it to replace concrete FrameEventArgs type in more places. TODO: Discuss path for IViewManager, NativeModuleBase, and ReactContextNativeModuleBase, which are holding back other pure interfaces such as IReactPackage. Adjust CLI template and npm packaging to include ReactNative.Interfaces.

title: Fix file access to future access list in network module
body:
Hi, I would like to merge my fix for the network module. 
This code enables access to files with future access token instead of local filesystem path.

title: DO NOT MERGE: Update `ActionQueue` contract so it never returns null
References `_settings` for `JavaScriptProxyHost`
body: Addresses my concern in #358 that the remote debugger (`JavaScriptProxyHost`) is not utilizing the same url as `DebugServerHost`.

title: WPF version. When the debugger is open reload hanged
body: This is a fix when the debugger is open that no reload was possible anymore.

title: Track pending JS calls to delay Instance being destroyed
body:
There can be a race when some async (or sync) calls to Native Modules happen, an app shutdown is requested, the Bridge is destroyed, but then the JS calls return. This was noticed and fixed upstream in RN Android Java:
https://github.com/facebook/react-native/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=incrementPendingJSCalls&type=

The Java implementation was transliterated/replicated in an RN Windows fork to successfully fix and prevent this class of issues.

title: Animations lagging when theres an Animated gif in the view.
body:
Windows 10 x64 15063

1. `react-native -v`: react-native-cli: 1.0.0 react-native: 0.50.3
2. `npm ls rnpm-plugin-windows`: rnpm-plugin-windows@0.2.8
3. `npm ls react-native-windows`: react-native-windows@0.50.0-rc.2
4. `node -v`: v8.9.0
5. `npm -v`: 5.5.1
6. `yarn --version`<!-- (if you use Yarn) -->:

Then, specify:

<!-- (What platform are you building for? Choose any from UWP, WPF) -->UWP
- Target Platform: x86, x64

<!-- (What framework version are you building for? Choose from 10.0.14393, 10.0.10586, 10.0.10240, etc. (UWP), .NET 4.6.1, .NET 4.5, etc. (WPF) -->
- Target Platform Version(s): 10.0.14393

<!-- (What device(s) are you targeting? Choose any from Desktop, Mobile (ARM), Mobile Emulator, Xbox, Hololens) -->
- Target Device(s): Desktop

<!-- Which operating system are you using? Specify macOS, Windows, or Linux, along with specific release versions -->
- Development Operating System: Windows 10 x64 15063

<!-- Which version of Visual Studio are you using? Specify Visual Studio 2015 or Visual Studio 2017 -->
- Visual Studio Version: Visual Studio 2017


### Steps to Reproduce

1. Use this code
```
constructor(props) {
  super(props);
  this.ft = new Animated.Value(0);
}
componentDidMount() {
  this.animate(this.ft, 15000);
}	
animate(img, time) {
  img.setValue(0);
  Animated.timing(img, {toValue: 1, duration: time, easing: Easing.linear, useNativeDriver: true}).start(()=> this.animate(img, time));
}
render() {
const spin = this.ft.interpolate({
  inputRange: [0, 1],
  outputRange: ['0deg', '360deg']
})
return(
<View style={{flex:1}}>
<Image source={require('../assets/city.gif')} style={{position: 'absolute', width: screenWidth, height: screenHeight}/>
  <View pointerEvents={'none'} style = {{position: 'absolute'}}>
    <Animated.Image source={somePNGsource} style={{resizeMode: 'contain',
		alignSelf: 'center', width: 300, height: 300, transform:
      [{rotate: spin}]}]}/>
  </View>
</View>
}
```
### Expected Behavior

Smooth Animation. ( Like it was with the same code, on RN0.49.5 with RNW@0.49.0-rc.2 version)

### Actual Behavior

Animations play for about 1.5 sec then gets stuck for multiple seconds then play again and then lag and so on. Its like watching a 1080p video on a 256k modem connection.
UNLESS, you put your Animated.Image in a TouchableOpacity and keep it pressed/clicked/tapped while moving your finger/mouse. Its like constant inputs keeps it playing.
Without that, everything keeps laggnig UNTIL eventually, the gif stops playing and THEN the animation becomes smooth.
( btw my PNGs being animated are 2k+ in resolution and animated gifs are 50mb+ in size )
